snippet: Flight 804, carrying 66 people en route to Cairo from Paris, disappeared shortly before it was due to land. The reason was unclear, but the developments touched off fears about terrorism.
abstract: EgyptAir Flight 804, jetliner carrying at least 66 people from dozen countries en route to Cairo, is presumed to have crashed into Mediterranean Sea; Egyptian officials say terrorism is more likely cause for plane's disappearance than mechanical problems, though no group has yet claimed responsibility; mystery raises questions about vulnerability of civilian flights to terrorism.

byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH and KAREEM FAHIM
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nour Youssef from Cairo; Dimitris Bounias, Niki Kitsantonis and Nikolas Leontopoulos from Athens; Liz Alderman, Aurelien Breeden, Sewell Chan, Nicola Clark, Daphné Anglès and Benoît Morenne from Paris; Alissa J. Rubin from Brussels; Eric Schmitt from Palo Alto, Calif.; and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: Flight 804, carrying 66 people en route to Cairo from Paris, disappeared shortly before it was due to land. The reason was unclear, but the developments touched off fears about terrorism.

headline.main: EgyptAir Flight Believed to Have Crashed at Sea; Egypt Cites Possible Terrorism
headline.print_headline: An Egyptian Jet Vanishes at Sea Amid Dark Fears
